CABINET'OIL POSITION ...-Monthly Report lor November, 194-1, submittedby the Secretary for Petroleum..'.. -(Previous Re/port; Paper )7.F. (R.) (.4-1)68) ' - -'IMPORTS' -- '. ' ' ' . .; . ' ' - ..Arrivals. --Imports of Oil during November mere:- admiralty fuel Oil 257,600 tons, other Imports 993,100 tons, total-':- - --1,249,700 tons, as compared with a total of 1,-331,500 tons' in.October.',-.. i" :-'/i;H . / ' ' - 'MyM fevf; ":''.-'.'Indigenous ,-Products. - During November, supplies from -Indigenous Sources amoimted to .74,500 tons, malting a.total of1,423,700 tons.. since the outbreak of war. ' -'Tanker. Casualties; due.....to enemy action.During November, two British tankers (total gross tonnage ..-11,200) including one on. Admiralty service, and two British coasters,both in ballast (total gross tonnage 1,000),.were sunk. Three were torpedoed off the East coast and the quantity of oil' lost amounted-to 7,400 tons.vof "White Oils and 7,100 toils of Admiralty Fuel Oil,Six vessels were damaged as the result of.air attacks in and around home waters, but no oil was lost. - Two, were British tankers'',(total gross tonnage 13,700) including one on Admiralty Service,"one was an Allied-tanker' (gross tonnage 6,300) .and-three" were. ,British coasters (total gross tonnage. 2,200)v " ' ' ...CONSUMPTION ": - ,. :\ ' yServices, .IJ.K-., -'.:Consumption in November from U.K. stocks was lower- by 33,000*"-tons. The principal decreases were Admiralty Fuel Oil 16",000 "tons, .Aviation Spirit "Other Grades" 6,000 tons, "100 Octane" 5:,0QP tons,and War Office Motor Spirit 5,000 tons. - -"' . .service s, Ove r s eas. . . -':"'. -;, - vAdmiralty Fuel Oil" consumption showed 'a decrease in november and was 17,000 "tons "below the monthly average for the-second'year 'of war. ... :- j - -- -"''-' "' -: - Civil, ...y-, " Consumption in November (30. days.) was 30,000 tons lower thanin October (31 days) and the-same as in ^September (30 days)-.Comparison with September-shows that the 28,000 ton decrease inMotor Spirit has be-en balanced by a 24,000 ton increase in Fuel Oil. Admiralty Fuel Oil.U..K. stocks remained steady, while Overseas stocks increased,by 60,000 tons0Other Pe tr oleum ^Prpcluc ts. -ITotal U.K. stocks (excluding Admiralty Fuel Oil) increased durinNovember by 220,000 tons. Apart from Aviation Spirit (See below) increasesoccurred in Civil stocks of Motor Spirit 129,000 tons, Kerosene60s000 tons, and Gas and Diesel Oils 51,000 tons, while there weredecreases for Lubricating Oils 25,000 tons,, and Crude and Process Oil2.1,000 tons.Aviation SpiritsTotal U.K. - stocks of Aviation Spirit at the end of Novemberwere 842,900 tons of which 530,500 tons were "100 Octane" Spirit and312,600 tons "Other Grades".. This shows an increase over the endof October of 9,500 tons in total, being an increase of 14,000 tons100 Octane offset by a decrease of 4,500 tons other grades. Newsupplies (imports and home production) during the four weeks ended27th November? amounted to 71,100 tons0LOSSES OF PETROLEUM PRODUCTS DUE TO ENEMY ACTION.A statement is appended showing'the losses of petroleum productsdue to enemy action, differentiating between those intended for theuse in the U.K. and those for Overseas: requirements *GRAPHS. .U.K.. Import and Stock movements since the outbreak of war are shown in the appended.graphs.:STOCKS IN INDIA AND CERTAIN DOMINIONS AND COLONIES.A statement is appended giving information of the stocks ofprincipal petroleum products held in India, the Dominions (excludingCanada) and in certain Colonies as at the end of October, 1941.GENERALSplinter-proof "Walls -.; At the end of-November, walls had been completed for some"f920,877 tons of Civil and Service Tankage in the United Kingdom.In addition, walls were completed to the extent of 50% or more for 56,414 tons. .....Damage to Oil InstallationsOn 1st November, at STANLOW a barrelling shod was partly destroyed, and 10 Rail Cars were badly damaged, by an H.B. A Tanlcoralongside was slightly damaged bysplinters, but its discharge was completed.* ' . - - G.L.
